reviewTitle: Should Have Bought This Years Ago
reviewDescription: This is so easy to setup and use, I wish I got this years ago. I'll be honest, and I feel a bit foolish admitting this, but: Despite hearing about the Fire TV stick's existence for years, I never considered it because I thought there was a monthly fee! I didn't want to pay for anything beyond my subscriptions, so I never even read the details. I put my television in a box in the attic when I 'cut the cord' with my cable company in 2012 and it's been there ever since. I've been watching 'TV' on my desktop PC or on my Kindle.This worked well enough for years, but during the pandemic I began spending a lot more time streaming shows and despite replacing my desk chair with a more comfortable chair, it just wasn't ergonomic and became more and more uncomfortable, so I needed to reconsider my TV setup. Enter the Fire Stick! This time I read the details - and then re-read them, and then Youtubed videos about it, because I couldn't believe it really didn't cost anything per month! You just buy the stick and plug it in and that's it?! Yep!So here's a few noteworthy points: First, it does not use USB; I saw this pop up in the questions for this product quite a bit. Technically the wall adapter plugs into the included USB cord - just like your kindle charger, etc. But there's no USB needed for the actual television end, it uses an HDMI port and that's it. Interestingly, I almost didn't get it because I was sure the TV I bought back in 2009 wouldn't have an HDMI port, but I finally went up to the attic to check and sure enough, it has one! So be sure your TV has an HDMI port, that's required.Setup was ridiculously easy. Just attach the items in the box together and plug it into the HDMI port on the back of your TV and then plug the other end into a wall outlet. That's it! Then turn the TV on and the setup will walk you through the rest, signing you into your Amazon account, calibrating the included remote control, updating (several times), choosing streaming apps to start with, etc. It's all very simple.If you want to watch paid streaming services such as Netflix, Hulu, etc you must have a paid subscription to them. But there's other services/apps such as Pluto TV and others that are totally free and have a decent variety of ad-supported content, both shows and movies as well as news. And Amazon's apps are of course there, like Amazon Music and Prime Video (if you subscribe to Prime Video). I only have Hulu and Prime Video currently as paid subscriptions, but there's plenty of free content to supplement. In fact, I even have my local news which surprised me (they must stream on a live app and I never realized it).So basically, it aggregates various paid and free streaming apps to one place and this little stick presents them all in one nice looking interface, letting you use your remote to choose programming, just like TV. To be clear, the Fire TV stick runs off your wifi signal, so be sure you have wifi at home. On one hand it doesn't give you anything you can't get without it, but on the other hand, the convenience of having it all accessible in one place is fantastic and makes it feel like I'm getting all kinds of new content. Some of the apps I've never even heard of, so there is new-to-me content in that regard.The interface is excellent and fairly intuitive, and the remote works great. I am super glad I opted for the Fire TV stick option that comes with the remote that also has TV controls like volume and mute, so I can do it all with the remote that came with it. Now I can sit in my living room like a normal person and watch TV (streaming services) comfortably from my couch; I should have got this years ago.Just be sure you have:1. A TV with an HDMI port2. Wifi at home3. OPTIONAL: Paid services if you want to watch Hulu, Netflix, etc. Otherwise you can still use this to access free content.

We finally cut the cable, well, cable to the satellite Dish. We were spending a lot for so much stuff we didn't use. The problem: We were left with a smart TV that was not quite smart enough to allow install of the FUBO app and another that had HDMI ports, but nothing more modern than that. I was just about to pull the trigger on the Google Chromecast, but thankfully happened onto a Firestick review. I think Chromecast would have been adequate, but it's just a streaming device, allowing us to mirror what was playing on our phones or computer. The two gadgets were in the very same price range, and the Firestick has *far* more to offer. In short, it converts a dumb TV--as long as it has an HDMI port and access to WiFi--into a very very smart TV. The Firestick has its own memory, so I can download and install apps for the various streaming services like Peacock hoping to nickel and dime me to death. A truly marvelous invention. I bought a second Stick for the oldish TV in our cabin and then a third for my mother-in-law to use at her rental condo in Florida. Each was a snap to set up and so far all have worked flawlessly. The remote is intuitive, but the fast forward/rewind function took some getting used to (YouTube TV's remote has FF/RW that is far superior) but we have adapted. So pleased I went this route! (We don't use Alexa or the voice recognition yet, so no opinion on that.)

Overall an amazing product! Amazon thought of everything and then fit it all into this little gadget. I'm an owner of an Apple TV and when the streaming box of one of my TVs broke, I decided to give the Fire Stick a chance since I didn't feel like dropping $100+ for another Apple TV. IT WAS THE BEST DECISION I'VE MADE. My initial impression of the Fire Stick was how tiny it was compared to the Apple TV. It wasn't a huge, heavy box that I had to lug around whenever I traveled, even to the point where it became too big of a hassle to bring. Instead, the Fire Stick is small, 100% portable, and doesn't weigh any more than a pen. So you can imagine how surprised I was when I found out that this little stick had more features and abilities than my Apple TV. The built-in Alexa is so much smarter than Siri and I love how it can switch between applications and do everything that an Alexa can do, the only big difference being that you have to click the Alexa button instead of being voice-activated (Maybe Amazon can add that feature). Installing it was super simple, all I had to do was plug it in and connect it to the power. The fire stick plugs into any HDMI port and if the stick is too long to fit in the HDMI section then you could use the provided HDMI extender which has a flexible cord. Again, Amazon thought of everything for this product. P.S. I must say that Amazon was super generous including the needed 2 AA batteries, a shock for big companies these days. The Fire Stick can turn any TV into a smart TV and add many features if you already have a smart TV. If you have an Amazon Prime subscription, you'll get access to Prime Video and a LOT of news sources (I'm not sure about what it'll be like without a Prime Subscription, sorry) But everyone can log into apps like Disney+, Hulu, Netflix, Youtube, and my new personal favorite, Spotify. My only concern with this product is how easy it is to lose the remote, especially if you're a very forgetful person like I am. Amazon does have replacement remotes that they sell, one even has additional features like the ability to make the remote play a sound to locate it, but even the basic one can go for up to $20 which is more than half the price of what I paid for it. Also, a little tip, I noticed that this product specifically goes on huge sales from time to time so I recommend waiting if it currently isn't on sale.  The Fire Stick is truly an amazing product and in my opinion, it belongs in the top tier of streaming devices.

reviewTitle: Great design, poor reliability and exceptionally poor warranty:
reviewDescription: I love the functionality of the Fire Stick. It is easy to use, intuitive, simple but easy remote. However, the reliability isn't very good . . . and Amazon obviously doesn't trust it to last very long either. It only has a 90-day warranty, which I believe is the worst warranty (for name-brand electronics) in the smart video-type business.Mine very quickly just started to get painfully slow. Watching movies on it is great, but everything else is painful. Clicking on what you want can take over 5 seconds to respond. Of course you get to a point that you think that you didn't click and you click again, then it takes you into whatever the next click would have been. I takes several minutes to get back out of that and to what you originally wanted to click on. Moving just from icon to icon is painful, and the voice control is nearly useless. You have to hold down the button for a really long time, then speak, then wait a while to see if it actually caught it (if it didn't, it looks the same so it's tough to tell if it got it or not). This started to happen after about 4 months and has gotten worse since. Yes, I've applied the updates (which maybe *caused* the issue?), and I don't add other apps other than what it came with. I only use Amazon, Netflix, and Disney+ so I haven't exactly overloaded it with apps.So to sum up, some work for a while and some don't. Amazon doesn't have enough trust in the product to even give it a 1-year warranty, and now I know why. With such a short warranty, the Mean Time To Failure must be pretty bad. If these tended to be robust, they could afford to put a normal warranty on them.

So, first off, I have using fire tv for years, it's my "go to".  I'm all in when it comes to Amazon, I've just always liked the quality.  So this is the first negative review of one of their products that I can remember doing but sadly I'm not a fan of this new fire stick.  Since installing it, my internet usage massively increased.  I didn't realize it until I got my bill this month, but had been given warnings by my internet provider that I was exceeding my monthly limit.  I just blew it off thinking I was just getting close to it and really had no idea how much I used each month or what my limit was.  This was the first time I saw the warning.To add to this is the menu that is quite beautiful but slooooooooow.  Netflix takes forever to load, hulu takes forever.  The menu has recently started showing warnings that I'm close to being out of space.  I look at the apps and I hardly have any.  Yet, I'm still trying to delete apps and its still slow.  I simply do not understand.  It tells me that the capacity is gigabytes, yet all the apps I have barely add up to one gigabyte.So I use Eero for my home wifi mesh and thankfully it has a great dashboard to help track down the bandwidth usage of every connected device.  Yesterday we were gone most of the day and all evening and came home and went to bed, yet Eero shows that the fire tv used nearly a gigabyte of data!  How is that possible for a tv that is off?One interesting thing that I noticed the other day was that I switched on the tv and it went right to showing some movie on Showtime, it didn't go to the main menu.  It was interesting but I thought nothing about it.  Now I wonder if while my tv is off, content is still streaming to the fire stick?  Is that possible?  It would explain the rapid increase of internet data usage.I do not recommend this version of the Fire TV Stick.  I give it a few stars because I liked the new remote with individual buttons for the main content providers (netlix, hulu, etc)Edit:  Last night I tried to do an update and it kept erroring out.  I believe because it was out of space.  I hardly have any apps on it, so it has to be something else that has gobbled up all my space.  So, I decided to start over and so I "reset to defaults".  The first thing I did when it was rebooted clean was make sure I had every update available.  Amazon had the option to grab my profile so I didn't have to add any apps, the ones I normally use were added (netflix, hulu, and plex).  Looking at my space now, I actually had a 1.5 to spare now and the menu was snappy and quick.  Also, my technical opinion on my massive uptick in internet usage is that when I turn off my tv, the fire tv keeps my connection to hulu or showtime alive and I'm still using bandwidth.  This is evidenced by occasionally when I switch on my tv, the first thing I see is a moving or show playing via one of my streaming accounts and not the main menu which is what I would expect.

reviewTitle: Well, I'm the proud owner of 2 new Fire TV Sticks...
reviewDescription: I had two perfectly good Gen 2 Fire TV Sticks which are now on their way to a landfill after an unwanted and unneeded update was forced on the devices and turned them into bricks.It started with apps failing to launch. They would start loading, then crash and go back to the home screen. Restarting the app, deleting the cache, deleting data, removing and reinstalling the app did not fix the problem. Then I rebooted the device itself. Bad idea. It is now stuck at the "Fire TV" splash screen. For two hours until I pulled the plug. A couple weeks later, the same thing happened to my other Fire TV Stick.I guess the up-side is that the new Gen 3 devices seem to handle streaming much better than the previous generation. And being able to restore the old device settings to the new one was a time saver. Still it is irritating to throw away functioning hardware because some knob-developer could not bother to do testing and debugging before forcing the updates out to people who do not want them.I, probably, would have purchased a Roku (or something) as a replacement. However, the <$20 price of the Stick would suggest that Amazon is selling these at a loss to keep people in their ecosystem. They are welcome to eat the cost. Some days I really dislike Amazon.

reviewTitle: Constant ads even though I pay for ad-free streaming; also missing Prime Video episodes
reviewDescription: I purchased the newest version of the Fire TV Stick (Nov. 2023) because I wanted a more standard remote; previously, I streamed everything via my Playstation. Unfortunately, whenever I use the Fire TV Stick, there are constant ads on YouTube Premium and Prime Video that I do NOT see when accessing these services through my Playstation or laptop. The whole point of paying extra for no ads is...no ads. It completely defeats the purpose to have constant ads breaking up my viewing experience when I use the Fire TV Stick (it's especially bad when I want to stream relaxing/anti-anxiety music for my dogs because out of nowhere THERE IS A SUPER LOUD OBNOXIOUS AD PLAYING every few minutes). I've also noticed that when I watch NFL Sunday Ticket on YouTube TV via my Playstation's YTTV app, I get some "moments of zen" (nice nature sounds/animal photos) instead of commercials but that doesn't happen when I watch YTTV via the Fire TV Stick.Also absurd...I can access more shows and more episodes of shows available on Amazon Prime Video when I'm using my Playstation than I can when using the Amazon Fire TV Stick. Unfortunately I recycled the box in which my Fire TV Stick came, so I can't return it. I don't even want to donate it to someone because I'd essentially be giving them something that interrupts paid content every few minutes to show ads. This Fire TV Stick is essentially garbage and I'm incredibly disappointed in Amazon.

I like the layout of the Amazon Fire Stick remote but in my experience their life span is abysmal.  In the last 9 months, I have needed to purchase a total of 6 of these to use with two TVs (one in the den that gets used mostly just on weekends and one in the bedroom that gets used daily, almost entirely in the evening only). Doing the math, these remotes have lasted me approximately 3 months each before each has malfunctioned in some way, requiring me to have to buy a new one (I’ve googled every method I could find to reset one of these in an effort not to have to purchase a new one, with mixed results but still, most haven’t survived past 3-4 months).  After the first couple died I decided I would only re-purchase when on sale.  At this point I’ve come to the conclusion that the short life span doesn’t even justify buying at a sale price.  Most recently, my Hulu interface wasn’t working right (it would literally kick me out of Hulu every 5-10 minutes while I was trying to watch a program; whether the program was live TV or a recording didn’t matter) and at first I thought the problem was Hulu but after seeing that Hulu didn’t have this problem on the other TV at that time or on either of our tablets I came to realize that the problem was caused by yet another malfunction of the Amazon Fire Stick.  So I decided to stop throwing my money in the toilet at that point and switched to a Roku remote (I have since purchased a second Roku remote for the other TV as well as that Fire Sick began to malfunction not too long afterward on the other TV, as well).  So fat the Roku remotes are working flawlessly and the Hulu interface is working correctly again (confirming the Amazon Fire Stick was the problem and not Hulu).  The only thing less than perfect (for me) is that the Roku remote doesn’t have a built-in “Hulu” button on the remote like the Fire Stick does (I mostly watch Hulu) but it’s literally only one extra click to open Hulu from the Roku’s Home Screen (instead of pushing a dedicated button right on the remote) and while I haven’t been using the Roku remote long enough to compare its longevity to the Fire Stick, it’d be hard not to top the average of 3 months I’ve gotten out of multiple Fire Sticks so I’m giving Roku my business now and we’ll see how this goes.  It’s 100% worth making one extra click to open Hulu if Roku has a better life span than the Fire Stick (again, I think it’d be hard not to considering how short lived most of my Fire Sticks have been).  I am a fan of Amazon branded products in most cases, but not this particular product as no one enjoys wasting hard-earned money on having to replace the same thing you just bought a few months ago over and over again, right.

This lead me to buying a 128gb usb stick to expand the capacity so I could download and store the apps that I actually want. The problem is that there are some apps that can't be moved to the usb. There were games I purchased that I simply had to uninstall, and guess what? I can't re-download them to my usb stick without repurchasing them. What a shady business practice and a waste of money! I was totally deceived and will be finding a streaming / casual gaming solution elsewhere.

Consequently, I have had to reset, re pair, and troubleshoot this remote sooo many times and after a while it just stopped working completely. It is also very inconvenient because if anyone else in the house wants to use it they cannot unless they have my phone. So now I have to purchase a new remote. Meanwhile, back at the ranch my original Gen 1 Firestick and its remote is still working.

reviewTitle: Great device until you use Amazon Prime on it. Update: even worse but hope.
reviewDescription: Edit:  Press and hold the home button for 5 seconds+ and you have an interface 90% better than the stock one. But...Wish I had gotten something else. Now I have "Try Alexa" literally every 5 seconds on the screen breaking every single "overview" of every application. Yes I have every single possible notification, popup, you name it OFF or in the case of inverted statements, the epitome of crappy interfaces, ON.This thing is trash. Already looking at buying/building something else and feel so bad I recommended it to someone I plan to buy/build something else for them on my costs.The only way to stop it is to go into, some not all, apps. (or hold home for 5+ seconds and use a minimal launcher)Original:The short of my personal recommendation is if you plan to use an Amazon Prime app get something else that has a different form of app. If you plan to use everything else then this is a good bit of hardware and software.Been using a Samsung TV for many years but its old enough the non-amazon apps are starting to not be supported. The firestick was on sale for a decent price and far less than building my own so I picked it up. Installation went well, I really like the controller and the level of apps and their performance is fantastic. Then comes Amazon Prime. I realize I am reviewing the app and not the device but it can't run a "different" amazon prime app. You are only as good as your apps end of day and the fact is this is an Amazon device and its Amazon's flag ship application that you'd think would be a match made in heaven. Rather its the other "h" word.So why the one star when I originally rated it three? Time teaches, in short.1)The inability to stop preview video causes massive problems with navigation from crashes and massive slow downs to it disrupting controller button presses and down right a gargantuan annoyance trying to navigate around. Seriously, your only option is to mute the auto-play previews not the actual video. All other apps I have tried that support this feature allow you to turn it off. Whoever came up with the idea to not allow it being disabled should be fired. If I want to preview something I'll watch this thing called a trailer. It is so bad while navigating the app I feel like I'm going to have a seizure due to the constant flashing and movement in the background that I have zero control over aside from not using the app.2)It defaults to one-click purchases. Yah, can't imagine why they did that. The real issue though is that you have to use "Parental Controls" to disable one-click purchases. Excuse me? What does this have to do with parental controls? I don't want myself, the "parent and owner", to be able to do this and I don't have kids. "Oops, pressed a button and just bought a 20 dollar movie.". Wow, moronic. Ok, so you disable it and now you are having to punch in a PIN every purchase and yet another password to remember. While I have not checked let me guess, if you forget your pin you have to wipe the device? Um, here is an absolutely genius idea, ready? Add a toggle to just turn off one-click purchases. BINGO. I want a million dollar check for that idea. I might even patent it. Make that two million since topic #1 I plan to patent too, button to stop auto video preview.3)My amazon credits for digital purchases don't show up even under the more options. On my Samsung I could click on the rent button and see exactly what was going to happen and even elect if I wanted to apply credits or not. Now, you see nothing. Searched the net and roamed around in the device for a good hour and I can't find a single reference to this. Granted I have only tried purchasing once but the only message I got was an email indicating the purchase and the cost. Pretty bad that I have to go log into my computer to find out what my credits are. Oh wait, 15 minutes of searching for that and I can't find it either and no its not under your redeemable section in account. I checked. It's "a mystery" or more likely just more epically poor "UI/App" design across the board.4)The entire 40% of the top of the screen is nothing but an advertisement that is again, annoyin. The "app bar" is limited to a tiny middle row and half the width. For the size of Amazon you'd think they could find some decent UI developers. "You think you can do better?" "Yes, game over.".5)Because of all this bloat and forced useless features the amazon app is SLOW and I'm talking at least 20-30% slower than even the poorly created apps I've tried for free streaming. That's pretty appalling considering its their app on their device and speaks volumes, I presume, about their developer, marketer and management teams.I am sure people will have some sort of "answer" to many of my points but not all and none will solve the elephant in the room. The epically poor design of a flagship app on a flagship device that, in my view, defines said device.The app is so bad I sincerely doubt I will be renewing my prime membership. I can't stand using it so much it's not worth the literal headache it causes, I am not joking.Amazon ruined a great device with tons of great apps with their own app. It's pretty much one of the worst UI setups I've seen on a streaming device. My nearly 10 year old Samsung TVs amazon app interface is still vastly superior and actually faster. Maybe all of the new devices out there have the same bloated, seizure inducing, rigged for accidental purchases outside paying the price of more annoyance and down right poorly designed app but it would be worth taking the time to find out if that is one of your targeted applications.As to my suggestion to amazon, presuming they read this or even allow it to post. Go look at some of the other apps and definitely those for free streaming because they have you beat by light years on UI design and user experience. Amazon does some great stuff but this app is not one of them.

reviewTitle: Remote would not turn on the TV
reviewDescription: After purchasing 3 fire sticks in January (2 for my sister and 1 for myself) which worked perfectly on my TV in my living room. So I decided to replace my old model fire stick in my bedroom to this new one, since the old one was starting to give me problems (I've had the old one since 2015). I never read the reviews because I had no problem with those I purchased in January 2022 so I didn't expect to have a problem with my next purchase. The first thing that should have caused me to have a little doubt is the fact that it was $20 cheaper than the one I bought in January. However, who doesn't appreciate a sale. But, give me a sale for equipment that works.I put it on my bedroom TV and it would not turn the TV on. So I decided to try using my old fire stick remote to turn it on and it came on (however, the old one could not be used with the new fire stick) so I took the new fire stick remote (you remember the one that wouldn't turn the TV on) and I tried to set everything up, it kept asking to reprogram the remote. After the 4th time directing me to program the remote and doing absolutely nothing, I decided to call customer support.The first person (a woman) was very nice, listened patiently to everything I said, but could not help me at all, so she transferred me to someone else (a male this time); Well, I never thought that anyone could be as awful as this man was. I explained that I could not turn the TV on with the remote, which meant that the remote didn't work (not turning on the TV should have been enough), I told him I used the old remote and then tried using the new remote, which I described above what happened. Well, this customer support person said, they were not going to send me another one, nor put in for a refund until we could trouble shoot it. I explained to him that I could not even turn it on, and there was no way I was going to use the old remote to turn it on, and then trouble shoot the new remote. I explained to him that if the remote won't turn the TV on, then evidently it's not working and it needs to be replaced. I told him I will return it and could he put in for a replacement. He said NO, because if I tried to return it, then UPS would have to trouble shoot it. WWHAT????? I have never heard of such.So, after wasting 30 minutes with him, I hung up, got back onto the Amazon website and requested to return it. Unfortunately, I didn't have the choice to get a replacement and I believe that was because I got it on sale for 19.99 plus tax and at the time of my return request, it had gone back up to 39.99. To, me that was poor customer service. If I tell you it doesn't turn on the TV, a replacement should have been sent out immediately and a return postage for me to return the defected one.By the way, I returned it via UPS and the woman thought I was crazy when I asked her if they had to trouble shoot it first before sending it back to Amazon.Now, that I see it's on sale for 24.99, I am going to (crazily) try to purchase another one. I am praying that it will work. For whatever reason, (judging from the reviews) there seems to be more that work, than those that don't work. My main issue is customer service. If your equipment (fire stick) does not work, you shouldn't have to go through what I went through (and others) to get a replacement. So, I am leaving this review to tell customer service, you have got to do better.If they look at my order history, they will see I order all the time, and have been a faithful customer for years. I, (along with others) desire to be treated better.

When playing Amazon Prime movies, shows, etc., the mouths moving rarely matched the audio, and it drove me NUTS.In addition to that frustration, I now have to click through another hoop when I click on HOME. Subscribe and Save is almost never on time, and often never ships, as they have taken my orders AND my gift card dollars for items that weren't even in stock, even though they gave me "delivery dates" within the week. Yes, I'm on a rant.... For this device, think twice.I will certainly modify this if I get any response from my Customer Complaint email.

Remember when Apple got a lot of heat for supposedly slowing down older phones with each progressing iOS update? I suspect Amazon may be doing something similar. I’ve also thought this about the Kindles but that’s not what we’re here for.When the fire sticks work, they’re great. Sure, Amazon Prime now has ads and less free content that’s actually good and a few apps run stupid slow on this device but the mobility and ease is pretty awesome. But now we have smart tvs and Prime is looking less and less worth the expense, I’m just not sure this device is worth it if you have additional options.I have two of these, one clearly older than the other but both within the last 5-6 years. I got one when they first came out but had to replace it because it began to freeze and stop turning on. Oddly, I had only about 3 apps on it at the time and always put it to sleep. But these things happen.My review comes from the life of these devices and the overall support offered by Amazon. The first one mentioned above only lasted a few years. The purchased replacement’s fancy Alexa remote never worked but this wasn’t discovered until about 32 days after purchase (just past return window) - the included batteries had done some nasty business in the back and no amount of replacements could make the remote work. Amazon refused to replace and suggested we purchase an entire new device. At the time they didn’t sell just remotes (they may still not), so we had to buy a generic one that has never been great. I’ve always been a little salty about that.Now here we are and my current fire stick is stuck in an endless update loop. It worked perfect 2 days ago, went to sleep on its own, and now this. For a few seconds there’s an update message, then it shuts off, reboots, and starts all over. Tried every trick online and given by Amazon staff in the help forums. (Which btw, why should we have to take a device that previously worked with a tv to another tv to get it to work?) Nothing worked, the remote isn’t even acknowledged, the device is getting hot. Guess that means we will have to replace or look to something different. How convenient for Amazon that an required update would make their device unusable. (Shoutout to them taking things like 3G/4G off kindles for free or the perma-shuffle with that last Amazon music app update.)

reviewTitle: Dear Fire Stick: I'm am leaving you.
reviewDescription: I read reviews by people saying how easy it is to set up. Perhaps they have far more time on their hands, because I started to get perturbed after the setup process decided it needed a third software update. That's in addition to the firmware update. Once it actually started, I was greeted with a video. Honestly, Fire Stick, you talk too damn much. Once we got past that, I spent a few minutes getting acquainted with settings. Wow, you know so much about me, but say very little about yourself, such as what the blue button on the remote is for. For a button being featured so prominently on your remote, you really should tell me what it does. While I'm at it, you really could use a setting to fix resolution, because I know what 4k should look like, and my TV said it was in 4k mode. I've known it longer, so I'll take his word for it.While digging through the installed apps, I searched for one so I can watch my cable channels from Spectrum. It shows one in the search, but you wouldn't let me download it, so I asked my friends Google and Amazon reviews so other people you date might provide answers. The consensus is that I can, by side loading the app, but even then it may not work. Something about regions. What?? Dude, the Roku I just started seeing offered to incorporate my Spectrum account with his services. That was easy peas, and he didn't need to do three updates in addition to a firmware upgrade. And he let ME easily change which apps go on my home screen, all without trying to get me to watch some ad for his services.For those still reading, at least there is a setting to factory reset your Fire Stick, and Amazon has a very good return process. It's just a shame they can't program a streaming stick with better manners and will easily answer your questions. Sorry, Fire Stick, we can't even be friends.

reviewDescription: I paid $18 for this, which is super cheap. You can probably get it even cheaper now, and certainly the low price is an incentive. (It's entirely possible that if I left the stick powered up all the time it would do the updates during "downtime.")Any pros? Well yeah. I guess if you want a stick that allows you to sideload android apps, this is a contender (and the only reason it gets two stars instead of one). I originally wanted to use it for emulation, but performance and storage issues were too much to deal with.Anyway, pay a little extra and get a device that actually works properly.

My religious organization wanted to stream some proprietary YouTube content for the congregation to watch, and the organization streaming it had given us URLs to access it.  Last year, as the wifi in the room where the viewing was to take place wasn't working, we tried Chrome casting, but we are a very small, elderly group, and only one or two of us have the combination of an Android phone, tethering feature enabled on our phone plan with enough data to support the entire set of sessions, access to the URLs, and the knowledge of (or rather, the ability to research and figure out) how to put everything together and make it work.This year, there was only one such person: me.  I didn't want to have to be there for every session, from beginning to end, so I looked for an alternative to Chromecasting.  The first step was to establish WiFi connectivity in the room - that was resolved by restoring the configuration that had somehow been wiped from the old wifi router.  Next was to get web browser functionality.  The congregation's Visio TV doesn't have a browser app, and the YouTube app doesn't have any way to enter a URL (not on the TV, not on my phone, not on my PC). reviewTitle: The REMOTE DESIGN compare to previous gets a ONE STAR / Updated 11/22
reviewDescription: I appreciate that I got this at a very good Prime Day price. I now have 3 Fire Sticks and am grateful to have them. This generation seems to work faster than the previous as well -- scrolls faster, responds faster. I don't generally use voice, because the previous version was horrid to even attempt, so I gave up long ago.Now here's the rub. AMAZON, YOUR NEW FIRE STICK DESIGN IS A FAILURE. Here's why:The new remote is great for those who never used the previous remote. The previous was more streamlined which made it easy to locate buttons without even glancing at it. The previous had fewer buttons so there was little confusion as to what you were pressing at any given time. The batteries were near the bottom of the remote which is where the bulk of the weight would rest perfectly in the palm of your hand.The NEW remote is the opposite of all of the above. First, there is no way I can find the play/pause button on this remote unless I physically look down at it. Even then, it's smack dab in the middle of a square of NINE buttons, plus 5 more. The mute and live TV buttons are placed so that it's easy to feel for them without having to stop to look at the remote (there is blank space below both). I am often pressing the wrong button when trying to play/pause. Yes, I could click the large round Select button at the top, but if on YouTube, it takes two clicks to pause, and the screen menu appears on the screen which takes yet another click to remove. All this means extra clicks (wear and tear) on the remote, extra battery power, and is a general annoyance.Now about the battery.. the batteries on the new remote are at the top which puts the bulk of the weight opposite of where most people hold the remote -- either in the palm or with the fingers. I have dropped this thing numerous times already because it feels unbalanced and top-heavy. It is unnatural for the way we're used to most remote controls. In addition, because I still have two other Fire Sticks with remotes that I still use, it is difficult to retrain my hands to use this clumsy, awkward stepchild of a remote just for this one device.Lastly, the new buttons for streaming services are nice to have, but not the greatest to have. If you truly have -- and USE -- all 4 services, this remote is made for you. Anything less than 2 or 3, and it's just another device with useless functions. While I appreciate being able to single-click to Hulu, I would much rather go through the main menu and get rid of these excess buttons. PLUS, most remotes have a different colored Power button at the top. Between the fact that these buttons being at the bottom + the awkward weight distribution of the remote, I frequently mistakenly hold this remote the wrong way and end up clicking incorrect buttons. I'm watching a video on YouTube, and with one errant click, I'm in that wild maze of a Live TV menu, wonder where I went wrong in life.AMAZON, HERE'S WHAT TO DO TO IMPROVE THIS REMOTE:1. Move the batteries back to the bottom right at the area where most people hold the lower half of the remote in their palm. 2. Move the streaming buttons to the top of the remote. 3. Move the mute, volume up, volume down, and Live TV buttons down into a separate section AWAY from the navigational buttons. Leave blank space below the rewind, play/pause, and forward buttons so we can again find these buttons without having to turn on lights and look down at the remote. 4. A more complete transfer of previous Fire Stick data to the new Fire Stick would be appreciated -- my transfer of data was incomplete. Why not allow a simply one-time cloning of apps via Amazon AWS so we don't have to spend an hour reinstalling apps we're used to?Until then, I'd like my money back or an exchange of this Fire Stick for an older generation like the other two I have. 1 star for the price, 1 star for the volume control, 1 star for speed. I'd take off more stars for the annoyances, however.UPDATE 11/2022:I still have the same bad review regarding the design of the new remote control. I STILL find myself grabbing it and holding it the wrong way which makes me click the wrong button (upside down, the forward button is mistaken for the rewind) and I use it daily. STILL hard to get used to. No product should be this difficult to transition to. NEW COMPLAINT: Actually, this is something I noticed right away, but can verify after extended usage. Occasionally, my Internet cuts out. On my laptop, I see that it is restored in about 1 minute. However, the Fire Stick takes upwards of FIVE additional minutes to have it's connection restored. Of course, I can EXIT the app I'm using, go to Settings, and go through the network prompts to get it to reconnect, but c'mon... really? The old Fire Stick would reconnect as quickly as my laptop. There is something off with this new device. Please fix, then send me another for review. /// I still greatly appreciate the quick buttons (Hulu, etc.. although if you don't use those services, the keys are useless and just more clutter) and the volume buttons.

reviewDescription: The installation of the direct stick was simple. Didn’t take very long. The speed of the device is pretty quick. Here ends the good. reviewTitle: Be prepared to purchase new every 2-3 years
reviewDescription: Since 2016, I have purchased three Amazon Fire TV Sticks with remotes included.  I usually have gotten them around Black Friday Christmas deal time.  The 1st purchased in 2016, the 2nd in 2019 and this 3rd in 2022.  The remotes are included in this review, since they come with the Fire stick.  The remotes are generally not worth their sale price individually.  In fact, the current sale ad shows a "fancy" remote for $29.99 and the packaged Fire TV stick with cheap remote for $19.99.  Seeing that the sticks and/or remotes usually don't last more than 2 1/2 to 3 years, I purchased a 2 year Square Trade extended warranty this last time in 2022.  Sure enough, the remote has stopped working and won't power up or pair with the Fire TV stick (which is still working).  I am having to use my phone with the FIre TV app to control the channels.  The old remote also controlled the TV volume and power, but the phone app does not.  So I'm stuck with the volume as it was when the remote stopped working.  I called in today for the warranty claim, and basically it involved calling Amazon customer service, as the Square Trade site recommended.  Apparently the warranty "fix" is to send me a refurbished remote, I have to send back the faulty one, and they will supposedly "repair" the faulty remote and send it back to me.  At least that's what I understood.Botom line, I love using the Fire TV Stick and have no issues with the way it works.  But be prepared to replace the Fire sticks every 3 years or so.  And buy the 2 year Square Trade Warranty (usually $3 during Black Friday period).  We'll see if I can squeeze another year out of the current stick and the refurbished remote that I'll be having to put up with.Thanks Amazon for dealing with my customer issue in a prompt friendly way.  I'm sure you do this because you know that the devices themselves are very short lived.

reviewTitle: Only if you WIFI is adequate
reviewDescription: The Fire TV Stick works if your WIFI signal is fast, strong, and reliable.  But in much of the USA (rural areas), WIFI is not as available as in other more developed countries such as China or in urban America.  I can go to the top of a remote mountain in China and my iPhone and WIFI still has great connections.  In American rural areas, just 40 miles from the capital of Michigan (no mountains, no valleys, no obstructions), I can show you many dead areas.  In the rain, snow, and windy weather, rural WIFI is often down.  Local storms will damage infrastructure often, meaning a week's delay before WIFI is working again.  Normally, my Fire TV Stick works about 60% of the time and when it works, it is very laggy. There are lots of hidden fees, often I have to resubmit passwords, and apps to download-- in other words the whole system is dysfunctional.  Finding what one desires is a chore too.  The system keeps trying to sell me things I do not want and imbeds things I desire. TV has become a madhouse of remote controls, paid content advertising, and the migration of sports to pay per view. In many ways the days of only 3 American TV channels over the airways was at the height of television-- the golden years. Now it is one big corporate jungle. I am not a socialist, but free enterprise does have limitations.I obtained the Fire TV Stick to watch the Uefa soccer tournament.  With the limitations of rural WIF, I see about 60% of the games.  It is better than none, but a D- in performance.  In theory the Fire TV Stick is an interesting idea, in application it has a long way to go, especially because of very poor infrastructure.  In the USA everyone is equal but some are more equal than others.  The Fire Tv Stick gets full, at its memory limit; then one has to manage the memory of the applications.  It is suggested that one get a USB external device to story applications.  The process gets so convoluted and involved, not a simple task, illustrating the poor standards of the memory consuming computer applications industry.  5 GB is not enough, and someday 5 terabytes will not be enough-- memory hogs.  It is a terrible situation.  There is a fair amount of memory irresponsibility in the industry.  It has been that way for 30 years.  No matter the amount of memory, it is never enough.  Computers do many things in the background, taking memory that rarely benefits the consumer.I urge everyone to travel the world.  It will illustrate both the limitations and the beauty of America. We have a lot of work to do. For economic reasons, rural America is treated as second class citizens. It is easy to understand the divide between the two coasts and the center of the country.  The Fire TV Stick illustrates this point well.My kids enjoy asking Alexa impossible questions, such as does Alexa have a boyfriend? or if Alexa enjoys hunting or fishing? This all came about as the kids watched a laggy Mandalorian and so had fun asking Alexa questions. Even though I signed-up for Disney +, the kids have no interest in it-- and maybe that is a good sign that they would rather play baseball or soccer or go swimming outside.  For sure, my kids are not impressed, neither am I.Update: Now after 6 months, I have cable internet to the house and the system works better, but still the kids call it very laggy, but it is better.  Connections to providers often disappear and require rebooting.  But the youngest enjoys Disney + now. I might consider buying a second fire stick. Technology is very ugly.

I love having the access to the streaming apps, and the interface is super easy to use.  However, this thing eats batteries for breakfast!  I've had this for 7 months, and often I just have to tell my kids we can't use it.  The app works minimally as a replacement for the remote.  Yes, I have tried all the trouble-shooting suggestions out there.  It just drains batteries.  I've tried Amazon brand, Duracell, Costco, doesn't matter. We are literally getting 24 hours out of a fresh set of batteries.  Would not recommend.

reviewTitle: We have switched from Roku to FireTV for all of our devices
reviewDescription: While the device works great for streaming, it still has room for improvement.We first started with Roku devices. Over time though, Roku devices basically stop working. They stop being supported, and even though they may have worked fine for years, you can no longer update them or install software, even old versions, so you have to throw them away.So, we tried firetv sticks. The first generation was rough, but they have come along way. For media streaming and app coverage, they really can't be beat..... but....We love that they are tied into Amazon, but also hate that they are tied into Amazon. It never lets you forget that its primary job is to let Amazon sell stuff to you and its secondary job is to be your streaming device. What do I mean by this? Well, it really likes to put you back on Amazon's homescreen as much as possible, and when you are in Amazon's homescreen, you are presented with the content you have paid for, but also a lot of content Amazon would like to sell to you. I really only want to see the content I have already paid for. For example, if you are watching something on MAX, or Netflix, and you pause the program, if you unpause it quick enough, it will just pick up where you left off. However, if you wait to long, you will find yourself back at Amazon's homescreen asking you to tell it which user profile to use. Well, unless I tell it otherwise, shouldn't I be the same person I was when I hit pause? Shouldn't I want to continue watch what I was watching when I hit pause? Once you select a profile, you are back to Amazon's homescreen where the show you ads for services they want to sell you, when all you really wanted to do was resume what you were watching when you hit pause.So then, you have to remember... what was I watching again? And what service was it I was watching it on? And then you have to navigate back to wherever it was you were and then and only then can you resume.So other than that, the device is great. I wish there was a way I could just pay a fee like you can on the kindle, to alter this behavior so its primary function is to be my streaming device, instead of to show me ads.This also becomes a problem if you have guests or visitors that don't understand this is how an Amazon device works. We didn't have a password set on the device and we had an older house guest that unknowingly subscribed to all sorts of streaming services and pay per view not realizing what they saw on the TV was not in our services, even though we already subscribe to more services than you could ever possibly watch.Lastly, the stick periodically has little flukes. Like we have the remote set to turn on the tv. One time, it wouldn't turn on the tv anymore. It turned out, it seemed to be turning it on, but then turning it right back off. Like when you hit the button once, it was sending the on off signal more than once. Unplugging the stick and plugging it back in seemed to fix it and then we could turn the tv on again. It happened in the opposite direction too. One time, we couldn't turn the tv off. We would press the button and it would turn off and then it would turn right back on again. Same as before, a reboot seemed to fix it. This doesn't happen often, but it is annoying when it does.As for Alexa integration, it usually works well, but sometimes, it just stops working. All of a sudden telling Alex to pause just doesn't work anymore. It just doesn't do anything. Doesn't tell you there is a problem or anything, so you have to go find the remote, even though you have paused it that way 100 times before.The wanting to take you through the advertising screens is a problem with the Alexa integration as well. You can't say "Alexa watch some movie on some service" and get taken to that movie. No, no, it is first going to want to know who you are, so you get to the profile selection screen. I should be the same person I was last time, unless I have logged out for some reason. Selecting a profile still doesn't get you to where you asked to go, it gets you to the Amazon advertising center. So then, you have to repeat yourself "Alexa watch some movie on some service", and then, and only then, will it do what you asked it to do in the first place.So the device, is great. But it is my device, and should focus on my needs more than Amazon's, but it doesn't. That is its only flaw.

I have used various roku devices for the past 10+ yrs to meet all my streaming needs. However, I had run into a few issues w my roku device about a month ago bc quite a few apps(most notably Prime Video) had completely stopped working, and other than scouring their community forums to troubleshoot my roku device, customer support was nearly non-existent(my device was an older model and did not qualify for tech support). The absolute frustration i felt after purchasing a 4k roku stick and a Roku 4k Ultra and finding out that neither were compatible with my older smart tv, I decided to explore other options. I landed on the Amazon Firestick(their most current basic model) after reading lots of reviews on the device. It was also important that whatever device I chose had to have a robust customer support portal to quickly and easily handle any issues that may come up. The Firestick checked all the boxes! Now, compared to my roku express, the user interface is a bit less intuitive on the Firestick, but I had a good understanding of it after spending about a half hour exploring settings, etc. One HUGE benefit of the firestick is that you can open up a browser and sideload 3rd party apps that aren't available in app store. Even the most basic firestick has the voice activated remote control! Haven't really experienced any cons yet, but I'll update if I do!

reviewTitle: Cut the Cord with Ease, But Mind the Processor Speed
reviewDescription: I recently purchased this product with the main goal of cutting the cable cord, and it did not disappoint. The setup process was incredibly straightforward, making it accessible for anyone regardless of tech-savviness. However, if you're a bit more knowledgeable about tech, you'll find that this device offers ample opportunities for customization, which I found to be a significant plus.The device allows for the installation and use of numerous apps, which is great for tailoring your viewing experience to your preferences. However, it's worth noting that as you add more apps and the device gets busier, you might notice a slowdown. When the processor is under heavy load, the performance can become noticeably sluggish, which can be a bit of a drawback if you're someone who likes to have multiple apps running simultaneously.Despite this, I would still highly recommend this product to anyone looking to move away from traditional cable services. It offers a user-friendly interface, the freedom to customize your viewing experience, and the convenience of having all your favorite streaming services in one place. Just be mindful of the potential for decreased performance with heavy use, and plan your app usage accordingly.Overall, I'm giving this product 4 out of 5 stars. It's a solid choice for cutting the cord, provided you can manage the occasional slowdowns when pushing its limits.

reviewTitle: A little cranky but great value
reviewDescription: I have purchased 8 of these over the years and I am still a fan..Amazon frequently offers these at discount rates, I purchased a replacement today for about the same money as 10 years ago and as soon as it turned on I could see an improvement in picture quality. Amazon stands behind its products and I always buy the extended warranty! For a small fee you are covered for a couple years. You won't believe how much free content you get take time to learn about the various offerings and the Alexa app makes navigating a breeze.Now let me say the fire stick is not perfect ...YET!!If you try to rush it it will turn cranky and sometimes needs rebooting or some other soothing but all in all its great.

reviewDescription: One of our first generation FireTV sticks failed [would not restart] so I decided to replace it with a current unit. reviewDescription: I have loved my FireStick as I previously bought the 2020 edition and used it religiously since purchase. I had decided to upgrade to the 2023 edition with their trade-in program. reviewDescription: I really love my fire stick. I will say, though, that I only got it because I wanted to control my tv with my Alexa devices (I had a Roku previously, which I was happy with). reviewTitle: Easy to set up, Don't be afraid to cut the cord on cable!

reviewTitle: Ruined By Software Updates - Slow, Buggy, Ad-Riddled
reviewDescription: I've owned this FireTV Stick for exactly one year now, and it gets worse on a monthly basis. The best way to describe it is like an early 2000s computer—painfully slow with intrusive pop-up ads that get in the way of everything you try to click on.When you turn on the FireTV Stick, you're greeted with a full-screen ad that autoplays video with sound. You can disable the video and audio, but not the ad itself. In order to access things like Netflix or HBO, you have to scroll "below the fold" aka past another two rows of advertisements (disguised as 'sponsored' or 'recommended' content).The endless ads slow the device down tremendously. It's easy to click a button on the remote, think nothing is happening, click again, then once the device catches up you've skipped past what you were aiming for in the first place. Apps take twice the time to launch as they used to. When I try to live stream sports, it often crashes and I'm brought back to the home screen (and have to navigate the maze of ads again).This is all a shame because the device could be excellent. I bought it for the simple yet powerful remote, which easily turns on by TV + Soundbar and controls both flawlessly. Setup is a breeze. The Alexa voice search, while slow, returns accurate results. It's affordable and basic, but meets all my needs from a streaming device.It's clear Amazon decided they would make money on this product through advertising, at a reduced upfront cost. reviewDescription: Was in the midst of watching TV tonight when the next episode of a show refused to load. I tried to hit the home button, but the Fire Stick wouldn't load. I tried using the voice commands, and no luck. I tried pressing the play/pause and select buttons simultaneously to restart the device. It got stuck on the logo page with the animation. I tried unplugging the device (for over 5 minutes) and plugging it back in, at which point it was stuck on the regular logo screen. I tried leaving it there for more than 10 minutes, and nothing happened.I got on with Amazon support. They asked me to plug the device into a different television, which I did, only to find that the logo wouldn't even load anymore. The support agent asked a number of questions without a lot of context (for example, which of my 3rd generation fire sticks was this -- the one I got at the store or the one I got on Amazon? How is someone supposed to remember which of the exact same fire sticks is which?).After about a half hour of troubleshooting on my own and about a half hour of working with the agent, I was offered 15% off a new fire stick. I told the agent I was frustrated, and that saving a few dollars (while giving Amazon even more) was unsatisfying. They went up to 25% and eventually 30%. While I appreciate that, they should have STARTED at that number if it was available, not wasted my time (after I'd already spent so much time troubleshooting).I'm not sure if there are better options out there, but Amazon should do a better job standing behind their products and actually replace broken ones. They shouldn't be haggling over a couple of dollars just to leave customers frustrated, exhausted, and unsatisfied.

While I would give this a 4-5* rating, the TOTALLY ridiculous way this thing works with regard to data usage is a KILLER…and not in a good way. I had to move to streaming since Directv dropped channels, and after settling on the somewhat pricier YouTube TV for my base package, added a small handful of other apps…I generally was aware I would see more data usage, I had 1.2 TB cap, and had used maybe 200-300Gb a month before, so did not expect huge issues.Boy, was I surprised! While we are a small family, we tend to have 1-2 TVs on a lot during the day, each with their own Firestick. But we are not crazy using a lot of higher res stuff. Nonetheless, within a week of more intensive, but now new normal usage, got word we were already at 75% of our “cap”. I immediately began researching how to control this, and have spent, so far, likely 8 hours fine tuning since we have 4 sticks in use throughout the house (of course, no more than 2 at a time).After all this effort, while the daily run rate came down a lot (some 40-50%), still had high usage, and finally figured out had to do with how one EXITS using the TV. Suffice it to say, NO, one does not simply press the off button in the device as this merely turns off the TV, NOT the stick, and NOT a show open using data. To totally shut down data, one needs to FIRST press the home button to get back to the main menu and FULLY exit the program or movie. BUT, to my dismay and chagrin, at times when one presses this, one first gets an intermediate screen which again does NOT stop the program from using data (one can still hear dialogue). So, one then has to AGAIN press the home button and wait to ensure the stream is fully stopped…This is flat out silly, and makes me wonder if Amazon gets a cut of the action from the data usage fees users will pile up! So, Amazon, how about next time having a simple on-off button which not only turns off TV, a minor detail compared to the $50-100 more one can rack up each month in excess data usage, but also effectively shuts down any send/receive on the FireStick. I am not totally familiar with other alternatives, though seems Roku literally has to be “woken up” after one turns off whatever its on-off button controls.Bottom line suggestion…before settling on FireStick, check out other alternatives…for sure, Roku (we tried but dropped because Roku did not have an internet app that could be used…

Roku has come along way with their streaming devices and Roku TV'S. I'm getting rid of all of my Fire Stick devices and outdated TV's for the Roku TV'S. reviewDescription: We got a this Firestick when our Roku finally broke after years of having it. We should have just gotten a new Roku!The Firestick is slooow. It freezes when turning on shows and stays on a black screen too often.We had our Roku connected to our Alexa show. My kids use the Alexa to pause and unpause the show they are watching. As well as turning on and off the tv. We got the Firestick because we were planning on connecting it to the Alexa as well. You would think since Alexa is connecting to another Amazon product the connection would be seamless. Not the case, half the time the Alexa won’t connect to the Firestick, or she indicates that she heard the command and nothing happens. Never had this problem with the Roku. We tried disconnecting and reconnecting and this issue just isn’t fixed.Lastly, the fire tv remote app leaves a lot to be desired. It won’t connect to the Firestick most of the time. Or if it is connected it will lose connection frequently.In short, we will be ditching the Firestick and returning to Roku! At the very least our Alexa will finally work it the Roku!!

reviewTitle: Very complicated to setup compared to Apple TV
reviewDescription: I want to like Fire Stick devices, and I have bought about 5 or 6 of them so far. Two broke after a year or two. I recently bought 3 more, along with an Apple TV, to cut my cord on cable TV.The Apple TV required literally 5 minutes to setup. I my iPhone next to it, the Apple TV had a chat with my iPhone, then automatically set itself up with my Wi-fi, and then loaded all the apps on my other Apple TV. Five minutes and it was done.Next, around 9 am, I started with the 3 Fire Sticks. It's now 5 pm and I am still trying to get the last stick to function.I am somewhat tech-savvy and know that my wi-fi is working at 50+meg based on a speed test. The high end router is close by. All my computers are working fine on the internet. The only thing that is slow is the Fire Sticks.All of the Sticks had the same problem; they would boot up, somehow connect to my wi-fi without a password, and try to download updates. They would there for half an hour without showing any sign of activity until eventually timing out. I did the rest-to-factory trick, tried again, and again, and again. The screen would show that the stick was trying to update the software, then advise that it was slower than normal, and then time out advising that I try later. Very frustrating. There was no progress bar to see if it was even working, which I now suspect that it was.If I waited long enough, and then rebooted the stick, it would install the first of several updates. I lost count of how many reboots and updates I have done today, with each one getting a bit better along the installation path. Meanwhile, my wife is enjoying the Apple TV that took 5 minutes to setup.Once I did get the sticks to work I had to set each one up on its own. There doesn't seem to be a way to "clone" settings from my account, or from another stick. I've been typing in my email and passwords for hours.  So I think these Sticks are finally working, but it was a long day of tedious hassles that I don't want to ever do again.My time is worth more than the $75 I saved with each Fire Stick (compared to the cost of an Apple TV). If I have to do this again it won't be with Fire Sticks.

I have owned FireSticks and Fire TV’s before. The Fire TV’s are the obvious best choice, having the software built into the TV itself.The FireStick’s are (used to be) pretty good. I never have issues watching movies and playing some games. However, the newer ones aren’t performing as well.This is the second “newer” one I have owned, and they don’t perform near as well as the older ones did. For starters, you have to buy special 3rd party adapters if you want to add a USB memory stick. Not having the adapter, and after you have installed the general apps allowing you to watch movies and tv shows, you’re left with around 1GB. And if you’re someone like me, who is disabled and not able to do much, other than watch TV all day; you want to download a few games to cure your boredom. Obviously, there are other things to do that would cure boredom, but I am very limited.As for performance; the sticks fall very short. Maybe it’s just the unit I received, as my previous one wasn’t quite as bad, but it is constantly crashing, it lags, the WiFi is very substandard (I have a gigabit connection which has a consistent 900Mbps, and the best I have gotten from this stick is less than 300Mbps on a good day), going back to the Home Screen after watching a movie takes far too long, etc.I am constantly having to go into settings and app management to clear the cache on every app. I’ll change the view to view the apps by size, and it will come back with two, three, sometimes more of the same app showing, and not all apps are shown. You have to exit the settings completely and try again, hoping it will correct itself. Sometimes it does, most of the time it doesn’t. And it builds up so much cache, that after a while, you won’t be able to watch movies or open apps as it tells you there’s not enough memory to perform that operation.I had to download a 3rd party app to complete the task. Even when the settings do work, I’ll go into the app, and the app will clear around 200MB of junk that the settings wouldn’t. So you’re almost forced to purchase one of the adapters so that it doesn’t crash.There are just too many issues involved, and it can be quite the pain.Don’t get me wrong, I love the Fire TV’s, and the sticks are usually pretty good as well, allowing you to watch movies on any TV. But I would definitely recommend getting a Fire TV instead of the stick. The ones I have found are very reasonably priced, and the performance by far outweighs the sticks! Being able to just plug in a memory stick is huge! You’ll have a much better experience.

reviewTitle: Good when it works; short lifespan with non Prime streaming
reviewDescription: This is about my 4th Fire Stick in about 8 years. When it's good, it is awesome - plenty of platforms, good speed, one remote, no monthly subscription, etc. I mainly use this for non-Prime streaming such as Netflix and HBO Max so IDK if your mileage would vary if you were primarily streaming from Prime vs (let's be honest) their competitors but it's only about 18 months before each and every Fire Stick I've owned starts having issues - video freezes up, buffering stalls out in low digits, no other remote functions make it better. I restart the stick, or in extreme cases, try a different port on my TV, etc. Maybe it works, usually it doesn't. If it works, you've still spent about 30 min of your time. Meanwhile, my desktop computer or phone (internet, not Fire Stick) has zero problems playing my show so I know it is the stick, not my connection, the Netflix server, etc. I'm grateful the price of the stick has reduced enough to make the short but brilliant lifespan of it mostly worthwhile. I've been down this path enough times that when you routinely have to restart x 3 to maybe get it to work, you may as well save yourself the headache and replace it right away because odds are it ain't you, or your internet, or your streaming service it is just what I would deem to be the predictable, premature death of the Fire Stick.

reviewTitle: Previous Firestick version was more user friendly.
reviewDescription: It's OK, but not very user friendly. If you've been a Firestick customer for a while, this new version does not seem to make significant difference.Most annoying (at least for me) is that the placement of the mute button has changed. It used to be in the center, right below the volume button, and with a single press of the fingertip your TV was muted. Now it's on the left side. In other words, if you have the remote laying on the table and press the mute button, the entire remote tilts to the left, unless you have a good grip on the entire remote. It's the little conveniences that can make such a difference! Why the 4 App buttons below were added is beyond me! You can easily glance at those apps once you're on the home screen. The TV icon on the right opens TUBI, which is also easily found on the home screen. Lastly the top button: They switched out the Microphone icon for the Alexa icon. I actually liked the Microphone icon better. For new users all of this will be of no significance. But if one knows how it previously was, there is an air of disappointment. Had I been more aware of the changes, I would have not obtained this version. Last not least: After setup, you need to download and reinstall all your former apps from the app library. I am constantly battling the "not enough space to update apps" message. When storage is now so cheap, it is incomprehensible to me that Amazon ever thought that 8gb is enough. Apple TV came in 64gb for a long time, and now has 128gb. Meanwhile, Amazon advertises their new Fire TV max with 16gb storage as the greatest new device with big storage. Not cool.EDIT: recently it also comes with DirectTV and Peacock buttons, WHICH ARE NOWHERE SHOWN IN THE PHOTOS! very dishonest advertising by Amazon.

You have the option of using an app on your phone as your remote so I used that until I couldn’t stand it anymore. The app was lagging and kept disconnecting from the stick and sometimes the app would go haywire and start doing whatever it wanted. I seen Amazon had 50% off for fire sticks for Amazon prime day. Basically it's just an as for Amazon't content, which is as dismal and vapid as you'd expect.I went back to using my console.For years I've been telling my friends, "One day we'll be saying 'Remember when Amazon was good?' reviewTitle: Hope you don't want to add apps for your subscriptions!
reviewDescription: Because Amazon INSISTS on bloating the FireTV stick with all the junk apps you don't want or won't use like Amazon Kids (41 MB), IMDBTV (123 MB), Silk Browser (145 MB), Game Circle (6 MB), Amazon Photos (39 MB), Alexa Shopping (15 MB),Amazon Live Shopping (36 MB), Amazon Music (64 MB) and, right now, Olympic junk) you already lost almost a half gigabyte of storage space on your FireTV stick. If you allow Amazon Kids to perform an app update, it doesn't overwrite the existing app but, rather, eats up the same amount of storage IN ADDITION TO the installed app. So, I have to conclude that any app update will also add more storage to the already crowded FireTV stick which, out of the box with NO additional apps, already has a bit more than half of it's 5.35 GB available used up with operating system.So, I subscribe to Hulu plus, Disney+, Peacock, HBO Max and Paramount. I can only have TWO of these apps download to the FireTV stick before it starts coming up and telling me I'm almost out of storage space. I go in and clear the cache, but the next day, same message, so, we keep Hulu on the stick, and only install any other app as we intend to use it. When we're done with it, we uninstall it again. It's a super pain in the…uh…well, it's a pain because you have to keep logging in every time the app is reinstalled, but it's the only way to keep it from freezing up and whining about storage space.Sure, I could spend MORE money and try to expand the storage, and perhaps that's Amazon's plan all along - I mean, I'm sure Mr. Bezos is having a tough time making payments on that super yacht, right?When not “overloaded” with more than two apps, it streams well and I find FireTV's presentation very intuitive and easy to navigate, which is why I gave it three stars. I'm just glad I didn't spend the extra money to have this aggravation on the 4k UHD stick which has the same amount of storage space.I miss my old FireTV - it was not a stick, a flat, square device that hung from the HDMI port and had TONS of space so I could have ALL my apps I use on it.Seems like every time Amazon “improves” something, it takes a step backwards.I would recommend a Roku stick over this one. It doesn't have these storage limitations.

reviewTitle: Layout seems complicated and messy, but may be a better streaming device than others
reviewDescription: Firstly, just FYI, another reviewer said that when you are watching, say, your cable TV on one HDMI port and  and want to switch over to another HDMI to watch Firestick, all you have to do is just ONLY press "Home" on the Firestick remote, and it will immediately take you to Firestick on the other HDMI.  This works.  Prior to that I had been confused, pushing various buttons just to accomplish it.Now for my HBO MAX story:I'm a female, retired senior citizen.  I have owned smart TV's, Roku boxes, and a smart blu-ray player for streaming services like Netflix and Prime, but nothing I currently own gets HBO MAX.  Therefore, I bought this Firestick just to get HBO MAX, which became a struggle, as follows if you'd like to read it.I had wanted to view a series which was only available on the new HBO MAX ORIGINALS streaming channel.  I didn't have any HBO subscription.  However, my cable provider (Verizon) was then offering a "deal" for a subscription to the regular HBO movie channels, ALONG WITH a new HBO MAX ORIGINALS streaming channel.  But, as my streaming device did not support HBO MAX, I bought this Firestick, which does, priced at $24.99 in Feb. 2022.  But then, after hours and hours of chats with Verizon and Amazon to fix the problem, my Firestick would simply not hook up to Verizon's streaming service.EVENTUALLY, after these hours of frustrating chats, Verizon informed me that they could not give connection service for any streaming devices unless I updated to a larger, more expensive channel line-up plan as well as purchase a new, high speed router for a few hundred dollars or rent it for $15/month, and in addition to that, a $100++ fee for a service visit to update my system to facilitate the new router.  However, my old, self-purchased Verizon router was still working, and doing everything I needed just fine, except getting me HBO MAX ORIGINALS.  Also, a few years ago when I tried one of Verizon's faster routers, the speed increase would not work well with my old laptop so I returned that router and just went on with my old equipment until now.  But it won't get me HBO MAX ORIGINALS streaming.As an alternative to all this, Firestick was offering a $15/mo. subscription to HBO MAX with HBO MAX ORIGINALS streaming channel, using Amazon instead of Verizon as provider.  So, I decided to just purchase that, and it hooked up right away just fine.  I watched the whole series I had wanted to see, and then decided to cancel, as there was nothing else that plan seemed to offer but a few more "MAX ORIGINALS" along with a list of past HBO movies you can stream if you want to.  I decided to stay with Verizon's HBO subscription instead, because I was enjoying the usual HBO live TV movie channels and didn't want to give them up.So, my "free deal" from Verizon for both HBO and the MAX ORIGINALS streaming channel, for $15/month, never happened, with only the promise that the new, expensive router would work.  Maybe I'm just not keepin' up, but would rather save my money for now.
